reason.tex:
%text One only needs to see the slopes of the lines to know that at both $A$ and $B$, the rate of change \underline\text{before} the point is different from the rate of change \underline\text{after} the point Hence, $f(x)$ is not differentiable at $A$ or $B$ Mathematically, we would say % \begin{align}
\lim_{x\to A^-} f'(x) &\neq \lim_{x\to A^+} f'(x) \\ \lim_{x\to B^-} f'(x) &\neq \lim_{x\to B^+} f'(x) \end{align} %text %
